The judges rose to their feet. Zara Kalu clapped with a satisfied, proprietary smile. Chief Obinna offered a series of slow, deliberate claps, a king applauding a jester who had learned his lesson. It was Femi Rhymz who looked genuinely pained, his applause seeming reluctant. “Welcome back, Adebayo,” he said when the noise died down, his voice heavy. “It takes a big man to admit his faults, and an even bigger one to sing with such… humility. That was a beautiful performance.” The praise felt like acid. They were applauding his chains, celebrating the strength of his cage.

Backstage, the spell was broken. The atmosphere had shifted once more. He was no longer a ghost; he was a tame lion, an object of pity. Contestants who had feared him now patted his shoulder with condescending sympathy. “Tough night, man, but you handled it,” one said. “That took guts,” said another, though his eyes said it took a complete lack of them. MC Slate was standing by the door of the dressing room as Adebayo approached. He didn’t offer a platitude. He simply met Adebayo’s gaze and gave a single, slow nod, a gesture that conveyed a universe of shared, bitter understanding. It was a soldier’s salute to a fallen comrade.

Adebayo found a quiet corridor, the sounds of the show fading behind him, and dialled Funke’s number. He felt hollowed out, a vessel emptied of everything that made him himself. She answered instantly. "I watched," she said, her voice quiet, steady. He waited, bracing for what might come next. "It was a beautiful song," she continued, and his heart sank. She had seen the puppet, not the man. "And your apology," she added, "was very convincing." He squeezed his eyes shut, the shame a physical heat on his face. Then, after a pause, her voice changed, losing its formal distance, becoming the voice he knew, the voice that anchored him. "But I did not hear the apology," she whispered, her voice dropping so low it was almost a secret. "And I did not hear the song they gave you." He held his breath. "I heard you building a bridge, my love," she said, her voice thick with unshed tears. "I heard every single stone you laid down. We are on the other side, Adebayo. We are safe, because of you." In the sterile hallway of the studio, surrounded by the architecture of his defeat, Adebayo leaned his head against the cool wall and cried, silent tears of grief and gratitude tracking paths through the makeup on his face. He had lost the war, but he had not lost everything.The days that followed his public apology took on a uniform, grey-toned stillness. Adebayo had become a ghost in the machine, a perfectly functioning component that drew no special attention. In the compound, the atmosphere around him shifted from pity to a kind of polite indifference. He was no longer the explosive, unpredictable force to be feared or revered; he was the tame lion, neutered and safe, and therefore, profoundly uninteresting. He would sit at the long dining table for meals, and the boisterous chatter of the other contestants would flow around him, their conversations about social media followers and celebrity gossip parting like a river around a stone. He was included in the headcount, but excluded from the lifeblood of the house. He had been reabsorbed into the background, a transition that was both a relief and a slow, creeping erasure of self.

His visits to the apartment in Ikoyi were his only anchor to reality, though it was a strange, distorted version of it. A black car would ferry him there twice a week, a silent driver navigating the manicured streets, the journey a passage between two different cages. He would step into the cool, air-conditioned silence of the apartment and find Funke trying to impose their life onto the sterile space. She would cook jollof rice on the gleaming induction stove, but the smell wouldn’t cling to the walls the right way. She would spread her weaving materials on the expensive rug, the familiar colours a small rebellion against the beige and cream decor. Amara was now crawling, a small, determined explorer charting the vast, empty territory of the living room floor. Each visit, Adebayo would notice a new change in his daughter—a new sound, a new dexterity in her tiny hands—and each discovery was a fresh pang of grief for the life he was missing, the daily miracles he had traded for this high-stakes performance.

They would sit together after Amara was asleep, the city lights glittering below them like a field of fallen stars. The television would be off. The shared silence between them was no longer tense, but thick with a shared, unspoken understanding. They were partners in a long, quiet heist of their own survival. "I feel like one of Mrs. Ede's friends," Funke confessed one evening, her voice low as she looked out the window. "I have not touched a Naira note that I have earned myself in three weeks. A man brings groceries in a box. I wear clean clothes I did not wash. I am a kept woman, Adebayo. I am safe and I am suffocating." He had no words of comfort that weren't a lie. Her agency had been the price of their safety. He took her hand, the calluses on her fingertips, once a testament to her hard work, now softened by a life of enforced idleness. Her strength was being leached away, and it was his fault.

The competition marched on. The theme for the next show was ‘Viewer’s Choice’, and the public, having thoroughly enjoyed the drama of his fall and redemption, voted for him to sing a soaring, epic power ballad about overcoming adversity. It was the most obvious, sentimental choice imaginable, and the production team was ecstatic. Diana coached him with a new, simplified mandate: just sound beautiful. His rehearsal sessions were models of efficiency. He learned the melody, memorized the breathing patterns, and delivered the song with the flawless precision of a studio recording. He poured no part of himself into it. He was a vessel, and the song simply passed through him, leaving no trace.

On the live show, he stood centre stage, bathed in a dramatic blue light, and performed the ballad. His voice was immense, filling the studio with its power and clarity. He hit the climactic high note with a technical perfection that made the judges gasp. It was, by any objective measure, a stunning vocal performance. The audience gave him a standing ovation. The judges were effusive. “Incredible consistency, Adebayo!” Zara praised, her smile wide and genuine. “You prove week after week what a world-class vocalist you are.” But online, the reaction was more muted. The hashtag #NaijaHeart, which had once set the internet ablaze, was quiet. The comments praised his voice but were missing the fervent, personal connection. “He sings like an angel,” one comment read, “but I don’t feel it anymore.” The public didn’t want a perfect singer. They wanted the man who bled on stage, and that man was gone. He was winning the competition, but he was losing his audience.

The quiet understanding between him and MC Slate solidified into a strange, unspoken alliance. They would find themselves in the same corner of the garden late at night, two smokers sharing a patch of darkness without needing to exchange a light. One night, Slate broke the silence. "How do you do it?" he asked, his voice stripped of its usual bravado. "How do you get on that stage and just… switch it all off? I watched you tonight. Your eyes were dead." Adebayo looked at the glowing tip of his own imaginary cigarette, a habit he didn't have but whose posture he understood. "I think of my daughter," he answered, his voice rough. "I think of the price of the food she is eating. And then I sing the notes." Slate was quiet for a long time, absorbing the bleakness of the answer. "My father took out a loan for my first mixtape," he said, the confession offered up into the darkness. "My whole village thinks I'm already a star. They don't know I'm deeper in debt now than when I started. We're all just singing for someone else, aren't we?" In that moment, the rapper from Jos and the caretaker from Lagos were just two men, trapped in the same gilded cage, trying to remember the sound of their own voices.

One afternoon, his phone rang with an unfamiliar number. He answered cautiously. The voice on the other end was hesitant, familiar. It was Bola, one of the younger security guards from The Palms, a good-natured boy who used to ask Adebayo for advice about his girlfriend. "Adebayo-sir? Is that you?" Bola whispered, as if afraid of being overheard. "It is me, Bola. How are you?" A wave of nostalgia, sharp and painful, washed over Adebayo. It was a message from a life that felt a century away. "I am fine, Bola. What is it?" There was a pause. "Sir, I just thought you should know," Bola said, his voice full of awkward sympathy. "The… your flat. The one at the back. There is a new family there. The man is the new head of maintenance. They moved in last week."

The words landed not like a punch, but like the slow, quiet closing of a heavy door. Adebayo stood on the lush, perfectly manicured lawn of the compound, the afternoon sun warm on his skin, and felt a profound, internal chill. He knew, logically, that life at The Palms would move on without him. But the finality of it, the simple fact of another family living in their space, sleeping on the floor where he and Funke had whispered their dreams, was a brutal confirmation of his new reality. His past had not just been left behind; it had been erased, painted over, occupied by someone else. The bridge he had built for his family was strong and it had carried them to safety, but he now saw with devastating clarity that it was a one-way street, and the shore he had departed from had already crumbled into the sea. There was no going home.The news about his flat was not a thunderclap; it was the quiet, inexorable settling of a building’s foundation. The structure of his past, which he had thought he was merely vacationing from, had been demolished and rebuilt in his absence. He was not on leave; he was obsolete. The realization settled deep in his bones during the following days, a cold and heavy truth. The scent of lemon polish and old dust, once the perfume of his life, was now a phantom limb, an ache for something that no longer existed. He had traded his world for a chance to save his family, only to find that the world he’d left behind had ceased to exist, making his sacrifice both total and irreversible.

This new, hollowed-out version of Adebayo was, to the producers, the perfect contestant. He was reliable, professional, and beautifully, tragically sad. He did as he was told. He hit his notes. He posed for the cameras. And he was dying inside. The grand finale was announced, and the theme was the one he had been dreading most: ‘Original Song’. Each of the final three contestants—Adebayo, a powerhouse female vocalist from Warri named Efe, and the ever-present MC Slate—was to write and perform a song that defined their journey. For Slate, it was an opportunity to showcase his lyrical genius. For Efe, it was a chance to deliver a show-stopping ballad of empowerment. For Adebayo, it was a death sentence. He had been so thoroughly deconstructed, so expertly coached away from his own instincts, that he no longer knew what his own voice sounded like, let alone what song it wanted to sing.

He sat for hours in his sterile room with a notebook and a guitar, trying to write. He attempted to craft the song they wanted, the one that fit the ‘Heart of Naija’ brand. It was a soaring ballad about a man who rose from poverty, a song of gratitude and triumph, full of sweeping metaphors about mountains and stars. The melody was pleasant. The lyrics were inspirational. And it was the most profound lie he had ever constructed. Every chord he played felt like a betrayal, every word a cheap imitation of the feelings he was supposed to have. The wellspring of his music, the unspent gold in his throat, had been buried under layers of compliance and fear. He could not find it. The notebook remained mostly empty.

His next visit to the apartment in Ikoyi felt different. The news about their old flat hung in the air between him and Funke, a shared, unspoken grief. She was quieter than usual, her movements slower as she went about the strange, listless rhythm of her new life. After they had put a restless Amara to bed, they stood by the vast window, looking down at the silent, orderly city. “It’s gone, then,” Funke said, her voice so soft he barely heard it. She wasn’t looking at him, but at the reflection of their two silhouettes in the glass. “Our home.” He reached for her hand. “It was just a place, Funke. Two rooms.” “It was the place you first sang to Amara,” she countered, her voice gaining a sharp edge of pain. “It was the place I held your hand when the power was out and you told me about your foolish dreams. It was our place. And now it is nothing.” He had no answer. He could only stand beside her, a co-conspirator in the erasure of their own history.

He expected her anger, her sorrow, even her blame. What he did not expect was for her to turn from the window, her eyes dry and fiercely bright. “So, this is it,” she said, her voice no longer soft, but imbued with a hard, brittle strength. “This apartment. This life of waiting for a car to bring you to us, of eating food someone else has bought. This is what we get for the price of that room?” He shook his head, lost. “I don’t know what you mean.” “I mean,” she said, stepping closer to him, her intensity a physical force, “that if we have given up our home, our life, our very selves for this competition, then you must not come back here with anything less than a victory. You cannot just survive this thing, Adebayo. You have to finish it. You have to win it. Not for them. For us. So that this… this gilded cage… was not for nothing. Go. Write your song. And win.” She was not asking him to comply anymore. She was commanding him to conquer. She was giving him his purpose back, not as a dreamer, but as a fighter with a final, specific mission.

He returned to the compound that night with Funke’s command echoing in his soul. *Finish it.* He sat with the empty notebook, but his mind was not on the finale or the judges. He was thinking of the bridge he had built. He had thought it was a bridge to safety, but Funke had made him see it was a bridge to this new, sterile world, a world where she was slowly suffocating. Winning was no longer about the money or the fame. It was about earning the right to tear down this safe house and build a real home, one of their own choosing. But the song still wouldn’t come. The weight of their sacrifice was too heavy; it crushed his creativity. Defeated, he pulled out his phone, seeking the one true thing in his life: a glimpse of his daughter. He scrolled through the videos Funke had sent. He found one from that afternoon. It was a short, shaky clip of Amara. She was holding onto the leg of a coffee table, her small body trembling with effort. She let go, her face a mask of intense concentration. She took one wobbly, uncertain step. Then another. And then she tumbled onto the soft rug, looked up at the camera, and broke into a wide, triumphant, drool-covered grin.

Adebayo watched the video again, and again, a sob catching in his throat. It was not a memory of the past. It was a vision of the future. It was a beginning. And in that moment, the song arrived. It came not as a soaring ballad of overcoming adversity, but as a quiet, simple melody, the kind of tune a father would hum while trying to build a foundation. The lyrics were not about rising from the dust; they were about laying the first stone. It was a song about the terrifying, sacred duty of fatherhood, about building a home not of bricks and mortar, but of love and legacy. It was a promise to his daughter, a quiet vow that her first steps would be on ground that was truly their own. He titled it ‘Amara’s Floor’.

He wrote through the night, the words and music flowing out of him as if a dam had broken. It was his voice, his true voice, unadorned and honest. The song was spare and beautiful, filled with the texture of his life—not the past life of lemon polish, but his present life as a father fighting for a future. The next morning, exhausted but exhilarated, he sought out the one person in the whole machinery he thought might understand. He found Femi Rhymz in a small, private lounge, away from the other judges. The Afrobeats star looked surprised to see him. “Adebayo. What’s up?” Adebayo stood before him, his notebook in his hand. “I have my song for the finale,” he said. “I wanted… I thought you should hear it first.” Femi raised an eyebrow, intrigued. He gestured to a chair. Adebayo sat, took a deep breath, and, without his guitar, sang his song, his voice a low, intimate hum in the quiet room. He sang of his daughter’s first steps, of the hollow echo in an empty, expensive apartment, of the promise of a floor that would belong only to her.

When he finished, the silence in the room was absolute. Femi stared at him, his cool, celebrity posture gone, his expression one of profound, unguarded emotion. “That song…” he started, his voice thick, “that is the most honest thing I have heard in ten years in this business.” He leaned forward, his eyes serious. “You know they won’t like it. It’s not a ‘finale’ song. It’s too quiet, too personal. It doesn’t scream ‘winner’. It whispers ‘truth’.” Adebayo nodded. “I know.” Femi stood up and walked to the window, looking out at the city below. “The Chief wants a product he can sell to the masses. A victory song. You give them this… you are handing the crown to Efe or Slate on a platter. You will lose the competition.” He turned back to face Adebayo, a wry, sad smile on his face. “But you will win yourself back.” He clapped Adebayo on the shoulder, a gesture of solidarity. “My job is to judge what I see on the stage. But as a man, Adebayo… as a man, I hope you have the courage to lose.”

parts.text:
The scent of lemon polish and old dust was the perfume of Adebayo’s life. It clung to his clothes, settled in his nostrils, and followed him home in the evenings. He pushed the heavy-duty buffer across the marble floor of The Palms Residence lobby, its drone a familiar bassline to the melody he hummed under his breath. The machine whirred, and Adebayo’s voice, a low and smooth tenor, rose to fill the space, chasing the drone and dancing with the echo in the high-ceilinged emptiness. It was a gospel tune, one his mother used to sing while braiding his hair, a song about faith and mountains and the mustard seed of a dream.

The machine shuddered to a halt. In the sudden silence, his last note hung in the air, pure and clear as a drop of water.

“Is that you, Adebayo? Making all that racket?”

He straightened up, his back protesting with a dull ache. Mrs Ede stood at the top of the grand staircase, her hands on her silk-wrapped hips, her face a mask of mild irritation. She was a woman whose wealth was as loud as the gold bangles that jangled on her wrists.

“Sorry, Madam. Just finishing the floors.”

“With all that… wailing? It sounds like a sick goat.” She descended the stairs, the click of her heels on the marble like a metronome counting his failings. But as she drew closer, the corner of her mouth twitched. It was a game they played. She would complain, and he would be deferential, and they would both pretend she didn't sometimes pause outside the lobby just to listen. “Anyway, the lift on B-wing is making that funny noise again. Like a dying man. See to it. Mr Bankole is complaining his guests were very disturbed last night.”

“Yes, Madam. Straight away.”

He watched her go, a galleon in full sail, leaving a wake of expensive perfume that failed to mask the scent of polish. He leaned the buffer against a pillar and wiped a slick of sweat from his brow with the back of his hand. A sick goat. He smiled a little. He had been called worse. His voice, he knew, was not for everyone. It was not the thin, reedy pop that saturated the radio waves. It was thick, like palm wine, with a texture of harmattan dust and a warmth that came from the very centre of his chest. It was the only thing in his life that felt entirely his own. Not borrowed, not rented, not beholden to the whims of the wealthy residents of The Palms.

His own flat, a small two-room affair tacked onto the back of the main building, was a world away from the air-conditioned splendour of the lobby. Here, the air was thick with the competing smells of fried plantain and baby powder. The drone of the generator outside was the constant, rumbling heartbeat of their lives.

Funke was on a mat on the floor, deftly weaving thread into a customer’s hair, her fingers moving with a practiced, hypnotic speed. The customer was scrolling through her phone, oblivious. And in a cot in the corner, a small mound under a light blanket, was Amara. His Amara. His heart.

Funke looked up as he entered, her eyes tired but holding a familiar light. “Ah, you are back. Food is on the stove.”

“How is she?” he whispered, his gaze fixed on the cot.

“Sleeping like the world is not on fire,” Funke murmured, not missing a single twist of her fingers. “Mrs Ojo came to collect the stew. She said to thank you for the extra ginger.”

He nodded, moving quietly towards the cot. He leaned over, his large frame casting a shadow. Amara’s tiny chest rose and fell in a steady, perfect rhythm. Her face, smooshed against the mattress, was a study in serenity. He could watch her for hours. This tiny person, this miracle of flesh and blood, had reconfigured his entire universe. Every song he sang now had her face in it. Every dream of a better life had her small hand tucked inside his. He reached in and gently stroked a cheek, skin softer than any silk Mrs Ede could ever wrap herself in.

Later, after the customer had left, admiring her new braids in the reflection of their small, cracked mirror, and the stew was eaten, they sat together in the near-darkness, the only light coming from the flickering screen of a small television perched on a stack of books. The generator had coughed into silence an hour ago, plunging their neighbourhood into a familiar, shared darkness.

“They are advertising it again,” Adebayo said, his voice low.

On the screen, bright, flashing colours exploded. A handsome host with teeth too white to be real promised “A NEW LIFE! FAME! FORTUNE!” It was the advert for ‘Naija Star Voice’, the biggest singing competition in the country. The screen showed clips of past winners: a young woman crying as confetti rained down, a man holding a giant cheque, a montage of studio sessions and cheering crowds. It was a fantasy packaged and sold in thirty-second bursts.

Funke sighed, leaning her head against his shoulder. Her hair smelled of coconut oil. “Ade, please. Don’t start with this thing again.”

“But you hear them, Funke. Some of them… I can sing better than them.” It sounded like boasting, and he hated it, but it was the truth. He had heard them. He had perfect pitch, a gift from God, and he could hear the slight waver, the strained high note, the lack of genuine soul.

“Singing in the church choir is not the same as this thing. This is for… other people. People with connections. People who can pay for votes.” She shifted, her voice laced with the hard-edged pragmatism that life had taught her. “We have Amara. We have rent. My hair business is slow. We don’t have time for dreams, my love. We have to be serious.”

“It is because of Amara,” he insisted, his voice rising with a passion he couldn’t suppress. “It is *for* her. Imagine, Funke. Just imagine if I won. We would have our own house. A proper house, with a garden. No more generators. No more pleasing Mrs Ede. You could open your own salon, a real one, not just… here.” He gestured around their cramped room, at the peeling paint and the single, buzzing lightbulb that would work again when the power returned, maybe.

“And imagine if you don’t,” she countered softly, her words a pinprick to his ballooning fantasy. “The money for transport to the auditions. The time off work. What will we eat? Hope?”

He fell silent. She was right, of course. She was always right. Her feet were planted so firmly on the ground they seemed to have grown roots. His were always trying to float away. He looked at the television. A new contestant was singing, a girl in a glittery dress. Her voice was thin but passable. The judges, famous musicians and producers, were nodding along with serious expressions. They looked like gods on a mountain, deciding fates. Could a caretaker, a man who smelled of polish and spent his days fixing other people’s problems, ever be allowed onto that mountain?

The next day, the thought was a persistent hum beneath the drone of the buffer. He scrubbed a stubborn stain on the third-floor landing, the words of a new song forming in his head. It was a song about a man with calloused hands and a voice full of unspent gold. As he worked, Mr Bankole’s youngest son, a university student named Tunde, walked past, his headphones leaking the tinny beat of an Afrobeats song. Tunde paused.

“Yo, Adebayo,” he said, pulling one headphone off. “Is that you I hear singing all the time?”

Adebayo straightened, wary. “Sorry, sir. I did not mean to disturb.”

Tunde laughed, a bright, easy sound. “Disturb? Man, you’re good. Like, properly good. You ever think of doing something with that? For real.”

The simple, unprompted praise landed in Adebayo’s chest like a stone in a quiet pool. “My wife says I should be serious,” he mumbled, fiddling with the handle of his mop.

“Serious? Bro, a voice like that is serious business! You heard about Naija Star Voice? The auditions are next week in Surulere. You should totally go.” Tunde tapped his phone. “Look, it’s all over Insta. You’d kill it.”

He showed Adebayo the screen, the same flashing logo, the same impossibly white teeth of the host. But seeing it on Tunde’s phone, presented as a real and achievable thing, made it seem different. Closer.

That night, after Funke and Amara were asleep, Adebayo stayed up. He took out his old smartphone, the one with a spiderweb of cracks across the screen. The Palms had Wi-Fi, a fast, unlimited connection for the residents. But if he stood in the corner of his bedroom, pressed right up against the wall that bordered the main building, he could sometimes catch a weak, stray signal. One bar. Sometimes two, if he was lucky.

He found the application page. Full Name: Adebayo Okoro. Age: 32. Occupation. He hesitated for a long time, his thumb hovering over the keypad. He could write ‘Vocalist’. ‘Musician’. But it felt like a lie. With a sigh, he typed the truth: ‘Caretaker’.

He filled out the rest of the form, his heart thumping a nervous rhythm against his ribs. He had to upload a video. He didn't have one. Panic began to prickle his skin. Then he remembered. Last Christmas, at the church’s carol service, Funke’s cousin had filmed his solo of ‘O Holy Night’ on her phone. He had been embarrassed, but she had sent it to him. He scrolled back through months of messages, past pictures of Amara, past shopping lists and funny videos. He found it.

The quality was poor, the sound tinny, filled with the coughs and shuffles of the congregation. But his voice, when it came, cut through the noise. It soared, filling the church, filled with a yearning and a reverence that even the tiny phone speaker could not entirely diminish. It was honest. It was him.

He attached the file. The upload bar crawled across the screen, impossibly slow. The single bar of Wi-Fi flickered, threatening to vanish. He held his breath, pressing the phone harder against the wall as if he could physically push the data through the air. The generator from the next compound over rumbled, and a dog barked somewhere in the darkness. He felt a profound and sudden loneliness, a man in a concrete box, trying to send his voice out into a world that had never asked to hear it.

The bar reached the end. ‘Upload Complete’.

A new button appeared. ‘Submit Application’. His thumb trembled. He thought of Funke’s tired eyes, of Amara’s soft cheek, of Mrs Ede’s sneer, of Tunde’s easy encouragement. He thought of the smell of polish, and the ache in his back, and the unspent gold in his throat. He closed his eyes and pressed down. The screen refreshed. ‘Thank you. Your application for Naija Star Voice has been received.’

He switched off the phone and slid down the wall to the floor. In the silence of the room, he could hear two heartbeats. His own, loud and frantic. And from the cot, the slow, steady, peaceful rhythm of his daughter’s sleep.

The week that followed was a quiet torment. The secret sat in Adebayo’s stomach like an undigested stone. At work, every drone of the buffer, every imperious summons from a resident, felt heavier. The scent of polish was no longer a perfume, but a shroud. He found himself checking his phone constantly, polishing the cracked screen with his thumb as if to clear a path for the message he yearned for. He would stand in the corner of his room late at night, a silent sentinel waiting for a single bar of Wi-Fi, only to be met with a screen full of old messages and the crushing emptiness of his inbox. He began to feel foolish. It was a lottery ticket, bought with a stolen scrap of hope. What were the chances?

Funke noticed his distraction. She saw the way his eyes glazed over while he was bouncing Amara on his knee, the way he’d startle when she spoke to him. She saw the new, obsessive ritual with the phone. She said nothing, but her silence was a question mark he could not answer. Her pragmatism had become a kind of fortress, and he had laid siege to it without her knowledge. The guilt was a constant, low hum, another bassline to the anxious melody in his head. He tried to compensate, working harder around their small flat, helping her more with customers, whispering compliments about her cooking. They were small offerings, apologies for a betrayal she did not even know had happened.

One sweltering afternoon, he was tasked with clearing a blockage in the drainage pipe behind the staff kitchen. The smell was foul, a thick, greasy stench of rot and old food that clung to the humid air. He worked with a plumber’s snake, his shirt soaked with sweat, his knuckles scraped and raw. It was the kind of job that made him feel small and unseen, a cog in the great machine of The Palms, tasked with handling its filth. He took a break, leaning against the hot wall and pulling out his phone. He didn’t expect anything. It was just a habit now, a nervous tic. He held it up high. One bar flickered into existence. And then the phone vibrated, a sharp, electric jolt against his palm.

It was an email. The sender was ‘Naija Star Voice Auditions’. His breath caught in his throat. His hands, slick with sweat and grime, trembled as he tapped the screen. The subject line read: ‘Invitation to Preliminary Auditions’. He read the first line, then read it again. ‘Dear Adebayo Okoro, Thank you for your application. We were impressed by your submission and would like to invite you to a live audition…’ The words swam before his eyes. The email detailed a time and a location: a conference hall in Surulere, the following Saturday. For a moment, the stench of the drain vanished, replaced by the imaginary scent of stage lights and new clothes. He was no longer a man standing in an alley knee-deep in refuse. He was a man with an invitation. He was a man with a chance.

That evening, he could not eat. The ball of yams Funke served him sat untouched on his plate. He watched her feed Amara, mashing the soft food with a fork, her movements full of a gentle, focused love that made his secret feel like a shard of glass in his heart. The television was off. The generator was quiet. The only sounds were Amara’s soft gurgles and the distant traffic on the main road. He knew he could not carry the secret any longer. It was too heavy, and too bright, to keep to himself.

“Funke,” he began, his voice barely a whisper. She looked up, her brow furrowed with concern. He slid his cracked phone across the table. “I did something.”

She picked it up, her expression wary. She read the email, her eyes scanning the text once, then twice. The silence in the room stretched and tightened until Adebayo felt it might snap. When she finally looked at him, her face was unreadable, a calm sea before a storm. She placed the phone down on the table with deliberate care. “Surulere,” she said, her voice flat. “That is three bus changes. The transport fare alone will be half of what I made this week.”

“I know,” he said, his own voice pleading. “But Funke, they chose me. They listened to the video from the church. They heard my voice and they chose me.”

“They chose hundreds of people, Adebayo,” she countered, her pragmatism flaring like a shield. “This is how this thing works. They call everyone to a big hall, they make you wait all day in the sun, and then a junior person listens to you for thirty seconds and tells you to go home. It is a business. They are selling hope, and you are buying.”

“It is more than hope! It is a chance!” He leaned forward, his hands gripping the edge of the table. “My voice… Funke, you know my voice. It is a gift from God. What is the point of a gift if I just use it to chase echoes in an empty lobby? What if this is the door He is opening? For us. For Amara.” He gestured to their daughter, now dozing in Funke’s arms. “I cannot spend my whole life smelling of polish and fixing rich people’s toilets and tell her that I was too scared to even try.”

The passion in his voice filled the small room, raw and undeniable. He saw a flicker of something in her eyes – not anger, but a deep and profound weariness. She looked from his desperate face to Amara’s sleeping one. She looked around the cramped room, at the water stain on the ceiling and the single pot on the stove. This was her reality, the one she fought to hold together every single day. His dream was a wild bird that threatened to knock it all over.

After a long moment, she let out a slow breath, the sound of a painful surrender. She reached down beside the mat where she worked and retrieved a small, knotted piece of fabric. Her ‘emergency’ savings. She began to untie the knot with her teeth, her gaze fixed on him. “The transport fare,” she said, her voice low and heavy with the weight of the sacrifice. “And enough for you to buy a bottle of water and one meat pie. Not two. One.” She pulled out a few rumpled Naira notes and pushed them across the table. They lay there, a tiny, precious pile. “But you must understand this, my husband. If you go, you cannot come home and tell me about the long queue or the hot sun. You cannot come home with just a story. You go there, and you make them listen.”

The morning of the audition, the air in their small room was thick with unspoken words. Adebayo woke before the first hint of dawn, his heart a frantic drum against his ribs. He slid from the mat, careful not to wake Funke, but her eyes opened in the gloom. She was already awake, and had been for some time. She said nothing, but rose and went to a small trunk in the corner. From it, she pulled his best shirt, a white button-down, now slightly greyed with age but impeccably clean and pressed. The sharp creases from the iron were lines of her reluctant blessing. She had also polished his only pair of good shoes, the leather worn but now gleaming with a dull shine. The gesture was more eloquent than any speech. It said, *I do not believe in this fairytale, but I will not have you looking like a fool while you chase it.*

He dressed in silence, the starched cotton of the shirt a strange armour against his skin. Before he left, he leaned over Amara’s cot. Her breath was a faint, sweet whisper in the stillness. He laid his large, calloused hand on her back, feeling the delicate flutter of her tiny lungs. This was the reason. This small, sleeping soul was the entire purpose. He could not fail her by not trying. When he turned to the door, Funke was there, holding out a small nylon sack containing his polished shoes and the bottle of water. Their eyes met. “Don’t let the sun cook your brain,” she said, her voice soft. It was the closest she could come to saying ‘good luck’. He nodded, took the bag, and slipped out into the pre-dawn darkness, the crumpled Naira notes a hot, secret weight in his pocket.

The journey to Surulere was a descent into the city’s roaring, waking heart. The first danfo bus was a metal box of stale air and crushed bodies, the conductor hanging from the open door, shouting destinations into the din of horns and market traders. Adebayo stood, crammed between a woman with a basket of live chickens and a young man with headphones blasting tinny music. The smells of exhaust, dust, and sweat were a world away from the sterile lemon polish of The Palms. He kept his head down, his lips moving silently, rehearsing the verses of the gospel tune his mother used to sing. It was a song about moving mountains, and right now, the city itself felt like a mountain range he had to cross. Each bus change was a new level of chaos, a new test of his resolve, pushing him further from the quiet predictability of his life.

By the time he arrived at the conference hall, the sun was a hot weight in the sky and the street was a river of people. It was exactly as Funke had described, but a thousand times more overwhelming. There were thousands of them, a vibrant, noisy, desperate sea of hopefuls. They spilled from the gates, lining the walls, sitting on curbs, each one clutching a piece of paper and a dream. He saw young girls in shimmering, tight dresses, men with sculpted beards and designer sunglasses, people with guitars strapped to their backs, entire families who had come to support their one shining star. The air thrummed with a nervous, competitive energy. It was a marketplace of voices, everyone trying to sell themselves. Adebayo, in his simple white shirt, holding his nylon sack, felt his carefully constructed courage begin to fray. He was a caretaker. A cleaner of floors. What was he doing here among these peacocks?

He found the end of a queue that snaked around the block, and after an hour of shuffling forward, a harried-looking official thrust a piece of paper with the number ‘743’ scrawled on it into his hand. Seven hundred and forty-three. He was just a number. He found a sliver of shade against a wall and sat down for the long wait. The sun climbed higher, beating down on the pavement. He watched as the day wore on, as the initial excitement of the crowd soured into tired frustration. He saw people practicing, their voices straining against the noise of the city. He saw others arguing, their nerves shot. He saw a young woman burst into tears after emerging from the hall, her brief, thirty-second chance already over. He clutched his number, the paper growing damp in his sweaty palm.

To pass the time, and to silence the growing voice of doubt in his head, he bought his single meat pie and ate it slowly, piece by tiny piece, making it last. He drank his water in small, careful sips. He was not here as a dreamer, he told himself. He was here as a worker. Funke’s investment was in his pocket, and this waiting, this heat, this crushing anonymity, was the labour. His job was to endure. He closed his eyes, shutting out the sea of faces. He tuned out the cacophony of competing melodies. He went to that quiet place inside himself, the high-ceilinged lobby of his memory, and let his own song rise, silently, in his chest. He wasn't Adebayo Okoro, number 743. He was a man with a voice full of unspent gold, and he had come to make them listen.

Hours bled into one another under the oppressive sun. Adebayo’s white shirt was now mapped with sweat stains, and his initial resolve had been baked into a dull, throbbing patience. He watched numbers being called in blocks, the hopefuls surging forward like a tide, only to ebb back out minutes later, most with their shoulders slumped and their dreams extinguished. The sun began its slow descent, painting the dusty sky in hues of orange and purple, and a cold knot of dread formed in his stomach. He had waited all day. Had they forgotten his batch? Had his number been a mistake? Funke’s words about coming home with just a story echoed in his mind, sharp and painful. He was just about to accept defeat, to gather his things for the long, shaming journey home, when a voice, strained through a cheap megaphone, crackled through the weary crowd.

“Numbers 740 through 760! To Gate C! Final call, Gate C!”

A jolt went through Adebayo, sharp as an electric shock. He scrambled to his feet, his joints protesting. 743. He was 743. He joined the last, ragged group of hopefuls, a collection of the day’s most resilient or most desperate, and was herded through a side door into the blessed cool of an air-conditioned hallway. The sudden change in temperature was dizzying. After the vibrant chaos outside, the inside was sterile and silent. They were lined up against a wall, a row of wilted flowers waiting for inspection. One by one, they were called into a plain, unmarked door at the end of the corridor.

When the door opened and a dejected-looking boy with a guitar slouched out, a woman with a clipboard called, “Number 743.” Adebayo’s heart leaped into his throat. He smoothed his damp shirt, took a deep breath that did nothing to calm him, and walked into the room. It was small and stark, dominated by a long table behind which sat three people. They were not the gods from the television. They were their weary, mortal underlings. One was a young woman who looked bored, her chin propped on her hand as she scrolled through her phone. In the middle sat a man with glasses and a serious, pinched expression, a pen poised over a notepad. The third was a sharp-featured woman in a colourful blazer, her eyes sweeping over Adebayo with an air of instant dismissal, cataloguing his worn shoes, his simple shirt, his age. She was the one looking for a product to sell.

“Name?” the man in the middle asked, not looking up.

“Adebayo Okoro.”

“Occupation?”

Adebayo hesitated for only a fraction of a second. He would not lie. “Caretaker,” he said, his voice quiet but firm. The woman in the blazer raised a perfectly sculpted eyebrow. The bored girl didn't look up from her phone.

“Okay, Caretaker Adebayo,” the man said, a hint of tired irony in his tone. “What will you be singing for us today?”

“A gospel song,” Adebayo said. “‘The Mountain of Faith’.”

The woman in the blazer sighed audibly. “Another one. Original?”

“No, ma. It is an old song. My mother’s song.”

“Thirty seconds. Go,” the man said, clicking his pen.

Adebayo planted his worn shoes on the floor, feeling the solid ground beneath him. He closed his eyes, shutting out their tired faces, the sterile room, the crushing weight of their judgment. He was not in Surulere. He was back in the echoing lobby of The Palms, his voice chasing the drone of the buffer. He was a small boy in a quiet village, his mother’s fingers braiding his hair as she sang of faith. He drew a breath, not of air, but of memory and hope, and opened his mouth.

The first note was low and smooth, thick like palm wine, emerging not from his throat but from the very centre of his chest. It didn’t just enter the room; it filled it, pushing into the corners, warming the cold air, silencing the tap-tap-tap of the bored girl’s finger on her phone screen. He sang of mountains and mustard seeds, of weary hands and unwavering belief. His voice, unadorned by any instrument, was an orchestra in itself. It carried the texture of harmattan dust, the warmth of a cooking fire, the profound, resonant ache of a life lived with more hardship than hope. It was a voice that knew labour and loss, but soared with a spirit that refused to be broken.

He saw the bored girl’s phone slip from her hand, landing on the table with a soft clatter. He saw the man in the middle put his pen down, his glasses sliding to the tip of his nose, his mouth slightly agape. He saw the woman in the blazer lean forward, her mask of commercial assessment cracking, replaced by an expression of pure, unadulterated shock. He sang past the thirty-second mark, past the one-minute mark. No one stopped him. He poured all the unspent gold of his life into that small room—the love for Funke, the fierce adoration for Amara, the years of quiet humiliation, the stubborn, secret pride in his gift. He finished the song, his last note hanging in the air, pure and clear as a drop of water, just as it had in the lobby.

In the sudden, deafening silence that followed, the three judges simply stared at him. The man in the middle was the first to speak, his voice a stunned croak. “Where did you learn to sing like that?”

“The church choir, sir. And my mother,” Adebayo answered, his heart still hammering.

“Adebayo Okoro,” the woman in the blazer said, her sharp tone now softened with disbelief. She picked up a sheet of paper from a pile. “You’re the caretaker from The Palms Residence who sent in the ‘O Holy Night’ video.” It wasn’t a question. She remembered.

He just nodded, unable to speak.

The man in the middle looked at his colleagues. “That… that was not what I was expecting.” He turned back to Adebayo, his eyes serious and intent. “Your voice has character, Mr. Okoro. It has a story. That is rare.” He scribbled something on a small yellow slip of paper and pushed it across the table. It slid to a stop just in front of Adebayo. “Don’t be late. And don’t wear that shirt.”

Adebayo looked down. On the slip were an address for a studio on Victoria Island, a date for the following week, and the words ‘CALLBACK – STAGE 2’. It was real. A tangible piece of paper that held the weight of a possible future. He picked it up, his fingers trembling, and folded it carefully, reverently, before placing it in his pocket next to the now-spent Naira notes from Funke.

“Thank you,” he whispered, his voice hoarse. “Thank you, sir. Thank you, ma.”

He backed out of the room, nodding his gratitude. As he closed the door behind him, he heard the woman in the blazer say to the others, her voice a mixture of confusion and excitement, “Can you believe that? A caretaker. What on earth are we going to do with him?” Adebayo didn’t wait to hear the answer. He walked down the empty corridor and out into the cool night air, the yellow slip in his pocket feeling warmer and heavier than any gold.

The journey home was the inverse of the one that morning. The city, which had felt like an adversary, a mountain of concrete and noise designed to crush him, now seemed to pulse with a shared, secret energy. The lights of the danfo buses streaking through the darkness were not just signs of traffic but bursts of confetti. The cacophony of horns and distant music was no longer a din but a city-wide orchestra playing a chaotic, vibrant overture just for him. Adebayo sat with his back pressed against the vibrating metal wall of the bus, his hand in his pocket, his fingers tracing the sharp, folded edges of the yellow slip. He kept pulling it out under the dim interior light, rereading the words—‘CALLBACK – STAGE 2’, ‘Victoria Island’—as if they might vanish. They were coordinates to a new world, a place he had only ever seen from the outside, a mythical island of glass towers and impossible wealth where men like him only went to serve. Now, he had been invited to perform.

He walked the final stretch to The Palms through the deep, familiar darkness of his neighbourhood, the generator silence a blanket over the huddled buildings. He could feel the exhaustion deep in his bones, but beneath it, a current of pure adrenaline hummed. He was no longer just tired; he was spent, emptied of all the anxiety and filled with a terrifying, brilliant hope. He knew Funke would be waiting, her silence a heavier judgment than any of the judges could have mustered. He rehearsed his speech, his great victory announcement, but the words felt hollow and boastful. He had no story to tell her, not in words. He only had the proof. When he pushed open their door, the room was lit by a single candle, its flame dancing in the faint breeze from the window. Funke was sitting on the mat, not braiding hair or sleeping, but simply waiting, her back ramrod straight. In the flickering light, her face was a mask of exhausted patience. She didn't ask a question; her eyes asked everything.

He didn’t speak. He walked past her, placing his nylon sack on the floor and leaning down to check on Amara, his ritual of arrival. The baby was a peaceful lump in the darkness, her scent of powder and milk a grounding anchor. Then he turned back to his wife. He sat down heavily on the floor opposite her, the candle between them. He reached into his pocket and took out the yellow slip, a bright flag of surrender in the dim light. He unfolded it and pushed it across the mat towards her. Her eyes followed the paper, then flickered to his face, searching for the punchline. Seeing none, she picked it up, her calloused fingertips handling it as if it might be coated in poison or pixie dust. She angled it towards the candlelight, her lips moving silently as she read the words. ‘Victoria Island’. He saw her shoulders, so tense just a moment before, slump with an imperceptible weight. It was not the happy collapse of relief, but the heavy surrender to a new, more complicated reality.

“Don’t wear that shirt,” she whispered, her voice rough. She wasn’t looking at him, but at the yellow paper, her mind already racing miles ahead of the moment, calculating costs and impossibilities. “They told you not to wear your best shirt. So what will you wear, Adebayo? A shirt made of hope?” She looked up at him then, and for the first time, he saw past the fortress of her pragmatism. He saw the flicker of fear, the terror of believing in something that could so easily be snatched away, leaving them with less than they had before. He saw the tiny, almost imperceptible gleam of pride she was trying so desperately to suppress. He reached across the small space between them and covered her hand, the one holding the slip, with his own. “We will find a way,” he said, and for the first time, it didn’t feel like a hollow promise. It felt like a plan.

The next day at The Palms was a study in surrealism. The lobby floor was just as vast, the marble just as cold, the scent of lemon polish just as pervasive. But Adebayo felt as though he were moving through it all behind a pane of glass. He was a man with a secret. The imperious commands of the residents, the drone of the buffer, the familiar ache in his back—it all seemed like a role he was playing in a film about his old life. He saw Mrs Ede sailing down the grand staircase, a scowl already forming on her face as she prepared to lodge a complaint, and for the first time, he felt not a flicker of intimidation, only a distant pity. Her world was so loud and yet so small, confined by the walls of this building. His was about to crack wide open. He met her gaze, offered a small, polite nod, and kept polishing, humming his tune a little louder than usual. The sound wasn’t a nervous habit anymore; it was a rehearsal.

Later that afternoon, while he was replacing a faulty light fixture in the B-wing corridor, Tunde jogged past, headphones in place. He skidded to a halt, reversing a few steps to look at Adebayo up on the stepladder. He pulled his headphones down around his neck. "So? Don't leave me hanging, man! Did you go? How was it?" Adebayo paused, screwdriver in hand, and a wide, genuine smile broke across his face, the first one he’d allowed himself all day. He felt a rush of gratitude for the young man’s easy, uncomplicated belief in him. “I went,” he said, his voice low, conspiratorial. “They… they want to see me again.” Tunde’s eyes went wide. “No way! A callback? Bro, that’s what I’m talking about! That is sick! Stage two?” Adebayo nodded, and Tunde let out a whoop, slapping the wall in his excitement. “I knew it! My guy! The voice of The Palms! What did they say? What do you need?”

The genuine joy on Tunde’s face was a balm. Here was someone who saw only the victory, not the problems it created. The judge’s dismissive words came back to him. “They told me not to wear my shirt,” Adebayo confessed, a little embarrassed. Tunde frowned, looking at Adebayo’s uniform. “Your work shirt? Nah, you can’t wear that. And your Sunday best is a bit… formal. You need to look like an artist, man. Cool, but humble. Like, effortlessly cool.” Tunde tapped his chin, his mind already working. “Okay, look. This is a problem we can solve. My wardrobe is your wardrobe. We are not the same size, not even close,” he said, grinning at Adebayo’s broad shoulders, “but my cousin, Dele, he’s a big guy. Plays rugby. And he thinks he’s a fashion icon. Let me make a call. We’re going to get you a shirt, Adebayo. We are going to get you a killer shirt.”

The next evening, after his shift, Tunde intercepted him by the service entrance. "Operation Killer Shirt is a go," he whispered, a conspiratorial grin splitting his face. He led Adebayo not to his own apartment, but up in the silent, carpeted lift to the penthouse suite, a realm Adebayo had only ever glimpsed when called to fix a leak. The door opened onto a space so vast and white it felt like stepping into a cloud. Floor-to-ceiling windows revealed the whole of Lagos glittering below, a carpet of jewels laid at their feet. Tunde’s cousin, Dele, a mountain of a man with a surprisingly gentle smile, was waiting. Laid out on a sprawling white leather sofa were several shirts that cost more than Adebayo’s monthly salary. They were made of linen and soft, brushed cotton in muted, earthy tones. Tunde held one up, a dark olive green shirt made of a fabric that seemed to drink the light. “This is the one,” he declared. “It says ‘I have soul, but I’m not trying too hard.’” Adebayo touched the fabric, his calloused fingers snagging slightly on the perfect weave. It felt impossibly soft. He felt a deep, squirming discomfort, the familiar unease of a man who polishes floors being dressed up by the men who walk on them. “I cannot accept this,” he mumbled, his eyes on the floor. Dele clapped a heavy hand on his shoulder. “Nonsense, man. It’s just a shirt. A voice like yours deserves a good shirt. Go on, try it. We’re brothers in this now.”

He carried the shirt home folded carefully in a glossy shopping bag, the crisp paper a foreign object in his world of nylon sacks and reused containers. He presented it to Funke with a nervous pride, pulling it from its tissue-paper nest like a magician revealing a dove. She felt the fabric, her fingers, so attuned to texture, immediately recognizing its quality. Her face, which had been cautiously hopeful, hardened. “Where did you get this?” she asked, her voice dangerously quiet. “It was a gift. From Mr. Tunde and his cousin.” He tried to sound casual, but the words came out sounding defensive. Funke dropped the shirt onto the mat as if it were burning her. “A gift,” she repeated, the word tasting like ash in her mouth. “So now you are their project? Their little charity case? The singing caretaker they can dress up and show off? Adebayo, do you not see? This is just another chain, a softer one, but a chain all the same. They own the building you clean, they own the flat you sleep in, and now they want to own your voice too?” Her words were sharp, each one a perfectly aimed dart hitting the exact centre of his own buried fears. “It is not like that, Funke!” he protested, his voice rising. “He is helping me. He believes in me.” “He believes in a good story!” she shot back, her eyes flashing. “And when the story is over? When they are bored? They will take back their shirt and you will be left with nothing but the smell of polish. We have Amara. We have our dignity. Do not trade it for a borrowed shirt.”

The argument left a ringing silence in the small room that lasted for days. The olive-green shirt hung from a nail on the wall, a silent, beautiful accusation. It represented everything that was pulling them apart: his soaring, reckless hope and her fierce, grounded fear. Adebayo found himself caught in the crossfire of his own heart. When he was at work, buffing the floors, Tunde’s confident optimism felt real and attainable. But when he was home, in the small space held together by Funke’s tireless labour, her warnings felt like prophecy. He would watch her braiding hair, her face a mask of concentration, and feel a pang of guilt so sharp it stole his breath. He was gambling with her peace, with their fragile stability. Then he would look at Amara, sleeping in her cot, and the fear would be replaced by a different, more powerful urgency. He had to do this *for* her, to give her a world larger than this one-room life, a world without the constant, rumbling drone of a generator. The night before the callback, he lay awake on the mat, staring at the silhouette of the shirt against the wall. It was a flag from a foreign country, and he was about to sail into its waters, leaving the only shore he had ever known behind.

Victoria Island was another planet. The air itself seemed different, thinner, cleaner, smelling of money and sea salt instead of dust and exhaust. The studio was an imposing structure of dark glass and brushed steel, a place so intimidatingly modern that Adebayo almost turned around. He clutched the address on the yellow slip, his only proof that he belonged here. Inside, the cool air hummed with a low, professional buzz. The other contestants waiting in the sleek lobby were nothing like the desperate crowd in Surulere. They were a handful of exquisitely beautiful, unnervingly confident people who looked like they had been born for a stage. They chatted easily with each other, name-dropping producers and vocal coaches. Adebayo sat alone in a leather chair that was too soft, the borrowed shirt feeling both too tight around his shoulders and too loose around his spirit. He was acutely aware of his worn shoes, of his calloused hands, of the faint, imaginary scent of lemon polish that he was sure clung to him like a second skin. He was an impostor, and he knew it was only a matter of time before everyone else did too.

“Adebayo Okoro!” The voice belonged to a brisk young woman with a headset. It was his turn. He followed her down a corridor and through a heavy door that opened onto a vast, dark space. He was on a stage. It wasn’t a room; it was a proper stage, a circle of blinding white light surrounded by an intimidating darkness. He could just make out the long table from the television adverts, and behind it, the silhouettes of the three celebrity judges. He recognised the sharp, elegant profile of Zara Kalu, the legendary producer; the relaxed, cool posture of Femi ‘Rhymz’ Adeoye, the country’s biggest Afrobeats star; and the severe, upright figure of Chief Obinna, the notoriously blunt owner of the record label sponsoring the show. The handsome host stepped into the light, his white teeth gleaming. “And here we have Adebayo Okoro!” the host announced to the empty, cavernous space. “He keeps the floors shining at The Palms Residence, but today he wants to see if he can shine on our stage! A big hand for our singing caretaker!” The patronizing introduction landed like a blow, but Adebayo barely registered it. His eyes were fixed on the judges, on those three fates who held his future in their hands.

“Mr. Okoro,” Chief Obinna’s voice boomed through the speakers, deep and devoid of warmth. “The preliminary judges seemed to think you were special. I am rarely impressed. Do not waste my time. Sing.” The command was a bucket of ice water. For a terrifying second, Adebayo’s mind went blank. The song he had prepared vanished. His throat closed up. He could feel the borrowed shirt sticking to his back, the weight of Funke’s fears, Tunde’s expectations, and his own desperate yearning pressing down on his chest. He was going to fail. The silence stretched. Zara Kalu leaned forward, a flicker of impatience in her eyes. He was losing them. He closed his eyes, and in the blinding whiteness behind his eyelids, he saw a single, clear image: Amara’s face, smooshed against her mattress in serene sleep. A breath entered his lungs. He would not sing for the judges. He would sing for her. He opened his mouth and what came out was a lullaby, a simple Yoruba folk song his grandmother used to sing, one he now sang to Amara.

It wasn't a song of power or glory. It was a melody of profound, heartbreaking tenderness. His voice, stripped of all artifice, became a vessel for pure, unvarnished love. It was the sound of a father’s devotion, a promise whispered in the dark. It spoke of protection, of safety, of a world made gentle for a beloved child. The voice that had filled a church and silenced a waiting room now created an incredible intimacy in the vast, empty studio. It drew the darkness in, transforming the intimidating stage into a sacred space, a father’s quiet bedside. He poured every drop of his love for his daughter, his guilt and hope for Funke, his entire being into the simple, ancient melody.

He finished the song on a note so soft it was almost a sigh, a perfect, gentle fade into silence. He opened his eyes, blinking against the lights, his heart pounding. The studio was utterly still. He could see the judges’ faces more clearly now. Femi Rhymz was leaning back, his head tilted, a look of quiet wonder on his face. Zara Kalu was staring at him, her famously critical mask completely gone, replaced by something soft and deeply moved. It was Chief Obinna who leaned forward, his elbows on the table, his fingertips steepled in front of him. He stared at Adebayo for a long, unreadable moment, the silence stretching until it was almost unbearable. Finally, he reached for his microphone, the click echoing through the studio. “Mr. Okoro,” he began, his voice a low, serious rumble. “I have one question for you.”

Adebayo’s mind, which had been soaring in the quiet, sacred space of his lullaby, came crashing back to earth. The question was not about his voice, his pitch, or his performance. It was a question about his life, a direct echo of Funke’s most profound fears, now spoken in a deep, booming voice from the darkness. He felt the soft linen of the borrowed shirt, suddenly heavy and foreign against his skin. This man was not asking about a song; he was asking for a soul.

He took a breath, the harsh stage lights hot on his face. He had no prepared answer, no slick retort polished by a media coach. He only had the truth, a thing as plain and worn as his own hands. “No, sir,” he said, his voice quiet but steady, the honesty of the admission silencing the vast room. “I have no idea. I have never been in this industry. I only know the industry of polish and leaking pipes. I know what it is to work for sixteen hours and have barely enough to buy medicine for my child. I know the demand of a boss who thinks my voice is the wailing of a sick goat. I know the shame of not having enough.” He looked past the blinding lights, trying to find the Chief’s eyes in the gloom. “You ask me what this industry will demand, and I tell you, I do not know. But I cannot imagine it will demand more than my current life already takes. If sacrifice is the price, then my whole life has been a down payment.”

A profound silence followed his words. In that quiet, Femi Rhymz slowly began to clap. It wasn’t a loud, performative applause, but a soft, rhythmic beat of respect. Zara Kalu, who had built a career on spotting commercial appeal, looked at Chief Obinna, her expression a complex mixture of commercial calculation and genuine awe. This was more than a voice. This was a narrative. This was a man an entire nation could root for. The Chief, however, remained unmoved, his face a mask of stone. He let the silence stretch, a tool he often used to break lesser men. Adebayo stood his ground, his heart hammering but his gaze unwavering.

Finally, Chief Obinna leaned into his microphone again, his voice a low rumble that seemed to shake the very floor of the stage. “This industry chews up young boys who want fame and spits them out as forgotten men. It has less experience with men who have something to fight for.” He paused, his dark eyes boring into Adebayo. “We will see which one you are.” He made a small, almost imperceptible gesture to the host. The host, his professional smile back in place, stepped forward. “Chief Obinna, the deciding vote…?” The Chief cut him off with a sharp look. “He is through,” he said, the words falling like stones into a deep well. “Move on.”

The walk off the stage was a blur. The bright lights gave way to the dim backstage corridor, and the tension in Adebayo’s shoulders unwound so suddenly he felt dizzy. The brisk woman with the headset met him, her expression now holding a flicker of respect. She handed him a laminated card on a lanyard and a thick folder. “Welcome to the Top 20,” she said, her tone all business. “Rehearsal schedule, contracts, and media guidelines are in the folder. Your life is no longer your own. Read it. All of it. Be at the studio tomorrow, 8 a.m. sharp.” He took the folder, its weight a shock in his hands. He looked at the lanyard. It had his picture, a grainy shot from his application, with his name underneath: Adebayo Okoro. Vocalist.

He found himself back in the sleek lobby, the other contestants now looking at him differently. He saw envy, curiosity, and in some eyes, a clear dismissal, as if his success was a fluke, a gimmick that would soon wear off. Tunde’s words came back to him: *‘The voice of The Palms!’* The host’s words echoed louder: *‘Our singing caretaker!’* He knew which label would stick. He was a story, a novelty. He clutched the folder to his chest and walked out of the glass building, back onto the planet of his real life, the cool evening air doing nothing to calm the firestorm in his mind. He made his way to the bus stop, a man caught between two worlds, belonging fully to neither. He pulled out his phone and sent a simple text to Tunde: *‘I am in.’* He couldn’t bring himself to call Funke. This news was too big, too terrifying, to be delivered through a wire. It had to be given face to face, a fragile offering laid at her feet.

When he arrived home, the generator was running, its familiar drone a comforting, mundane sound. The single lightbulb was on, casting a harsh, yellow glare over their room. Funke was on the mat, mending one of Amara’s tiny dresses, her needle moving with a quick, rhythmic precision. She looked up as he entered, her eyes immediately scanning his face, then dropping to the thick folder in his hands. She didn’t have to ask. The answer was right there, a heavy, glossy testament to his success. He sat down opposite her, the exhaustion of the day settling into his bones like a deep chill. He placed the folder on the mat between them. It lay there like a border wall.

“They put me through,” he said, his voice flat with fatigue. “To the live shows. The Top 20.” He watched her face, searching for a sign, any sign. She put the mending aside, her hands smoothing the fabric of her own worn wrapper. She looked at the folder, at the sleek logo of ‘Naija Star Voice’, an invader in their simple room. She looked at the olive-green shirt he was still wearing, a costume for a life he hadn't yet earned.

“So,” she said, her voice impossibly calm, betraying none of the storm he knew must be raging inside her. “They have you now.” He flinched. It was the exact fear she had expressed, now stated as fact. “They have our story. They will put us on television for everyone to see. Our room. Our daughter. Our life. They will package it and sell it.” She finally raised her eyes to meet his, and he saw no anger, only a profound, heartbreaking clarity. “You sang for them, Adebayo. Now you will dance for them too.” She reached out and touched the folder, not with fear, but with a grim resignation. “So show me. Show me the contract for your soul.”

They sat on the mat long into the night, the generator having coughed into silence, plunging them back into the intimate darkness of a single candle. The thick folder lay between them, its pristine white pages a stark contrast to their surroundings. Funke, with the ferocious focus she usually reserved for a complicated braid pattern, began to read. Adebayo watched her, unable to decipher the dense blocks of text himself, the legal language a thick jungle he could not navigate. He could only read her face. He saw her brow furrow at a clause about exclusivity, her lips thin into a grim line as she read the section on revenue sharing. The numbers were staggering. The label would take a percentage of everything: not just music sales, but touring, merchandise, endorsements, even public appearances, for a period of seven years after the competition, win or lose. It was a net cast wide enough to catch not just the fish, but the entire river.

“This is not a contract, Adebayo,” she finally said, her voice low and heavy in the stillness of the room. She tapped a page with her finger. “This is an indenture. They will give you a stipend, yes. Enough to make you feel rich for a month. They will put you in a house with the others. But you will own nothing. Your voice, the songs you sing, the clothes you wear, the places you go… they will own it all. It says here,” she pointed again, “that they have the right to ‘shape and exploit the artist’s life story for promotional purposes’. Exploit, Adebayo. They are not hiding what they will do. They are telling you to your face.” He saw the small, precious dream of a garden and a proper salon for her shrivel under the harsh light of her words. He had seen the callback as a door opening; she saw it as a cage closing, its lock clicking shut.

“But what choice do we have, Funke?” he pleaded, the exhaustion and the hope warring within him. “To stay here forever? To let Amara grow up in this one room, listening to the generator and the arguments from next door? This is a chance to escape. A hard chance, yes, a bad bargain, but it is the only one we have been offered.” He reached for the folder, his hand resting on top of it. “We have been exploited our whole lives for a few Naira. At least with this, the promise is bigger.” Funke looked at him, her eyes full of a deep, weary sorrow. She did not see a brave man seizing an opportunity. She saw her husband, a good and simple man, walking into a lion’s den because he had been promised a feast. She picked up the pen they used for her customer records and, with a hand that did not tremble, signed her name in the space marked ‘Spouse/Next of Kin’. Her signature was a neat, precise, and utterly joyless surrender.

The next morning, at an hour when he would normally be dragging the heavy buffer across the lobby floor, Adebayo stood with a small, worn bag at the gates of The Palms. A sleek black car, its windows tinted to an opaque darkness, was waiting for him. Tunde was there to see him off, bouncing on the balls of his feet with an infectious excitement that Adebayo could not quite feel. “My guy! You’re off! To the big leagues!” Tunde clapped him on the back. “Remember us little people when you’re a superstar!” Adebayo managed a weak smile, his mind elsewhere. He had said goodbye to Funke in their room, a stilted, awkward affair full of things left unsaid. He had kissed Amara’s sleeping head, the familiar scent of baby powder a painful reminder of the world he was leaving behind. Getting into the air-conditioned luxury of the car felt less like an ascent and more like an abduction. As the car pulled away, he looked back and saw Mrs Ede standing on the grand steps of the residence, her arms crossed, watching his departure with an expression he couldn't quite decipher. It wasn't irritation. It was something closer to… thwarted ownership.

The artist compound was a large, modern duplex on a quiet, tree-lined street in Ikeja, surrounded by high walls topped with security wire. It was another world, but a far cry from the sleek fantasy of Victoria Island. This was a holding pen, comfortable but sterile. He was shown to a small, neat room he would share with another contestant, a rapper from Jos named MC Slate who regarded Adebayo’s worn bag and simple clothes with a cool, assessing gaze. The house was filled with the twenty chosen ones, a vibrant and intimidating mix of talent and ego. They were all younger than him, their ambitions worn as brightly as their designer clothes. They spoke a different language, a slick patois of industry slang and social media trends, and moved with a restless, competitive energy that made Adebayo feel slow and ancient. He was the caretaker, the old man, the novelty act. He saw it in the way they looked at him, a mixture of pity and condescending curiosity. His story had preceded him. He was not just Adebayo; he was a character.

The first week was a blur of scheduled disorientation. They were given new phones with their schedules pre-loaded, new wardrobes curated by a team of stylists, and a strict set of rules. No unauthorized contact with the outside world. No social media posts without approval. Every meal was catered, every hour was accounted for. It was a life of manufactured ease designed to keep them focused and controlled. His first session with the head vocal coach, a woman named Diana with a sharp bob and an even sharper tongue, was a lesson in humiliation. He sang his mother's gospel tune, the one that had impressed the first-round judges, pouring his heart into it. Diana stopped him halfway through, a pained expression on her face. “Darling, no,” she said, her voice dripping with condescension. “That raw, shouty thing might work for a church hall, but it won’t sell records. Your pitch is a gift, but your technique is a disaster. You’re singing from your chest, from your feelings. It’s very… authentic.” She said the word ‘authentic’ as if it were a disease. “We need you to sing from your diaphragm. We need control. We need to polish the diamond, not just admire the rock it’s trapped in.” For the next hour, she had him doing breathing exercises and scales, trying to sand down the very texture he thought was the soul of his voice. He felt foolish, his large frame struggling to follow her precise instructions, while in the next room, a young girl half his age effortlessly ran through a complex Mariah Carey riff.

The calls home were the hardest part. He would find a quiet corner of the manicured garden, the new, unfamiliar phone feeling slick and foreign in his hand. “How is Amara?” he would ask, his opening line every time. “She has a tooth coming in. She is crying all night,” Funke would reply, her voice thin and tired over the line. “The landlord was asking about the rent for next month.” He would try to tell her about his day, about the stylists and the vocal coaches, but the words felt absurd and hollow. How could he speak of choosing between three different kinds of designer jeans when she was worried about rent? The chasm between their realities was growing wider with every call. “They are paying me a stipend,” he said, trying to offer a concrete reassurance. “It will come soon. I will send it all.” But he could hear the unspoken accusation in her silence. The money came at a cost, and she was the one at home paying the daily interest. He was living in a clean, quiet house with chefs and stylists. She was living in a small, hot room with a teething baby and the ghosts of their broken promises.

The theme for the first live show was ‘My Story’. When it was announced, a wave of palpable excitement rippled through the production team, and all eyes turned to Adebayo. He was their golden goose, their lottery ticket. His story was not one of youthful ambition or a comfortable middle-class dream; it was a gritty, aspirational fairytale that wrote its own headlines. The producers assigned him their top field director, a man named Tunde whose slick, easy charm felt like a weapon. He sat Adebayo down and pitched the vision for his pre-performance video package, his hands painting a masterpiece of sentimental poverty in the air. They would show the grand, marble-floored lobby of The Palms, then immediately cut to his own cramped quarters. The contrast would be breathtaking. They would film him with his mop, a silent, noble worker, staring wistfully into the middle distance. It was a caricature, a reduction of his entire existence into a thirty-second sob story, and Adebayo felt a hot, helpless shame creep up his neck.

The day the film crew came to The Palms was one of the longest of Adebayo’s life. They arrived in a white van, their equipment cases and confident swagger an alien invasion in the familiar service corridors. They followed him as he did his work, the camera’s unblinking eye a constant, silent judgment. The director, Tunde, orchestrated every shot. “Adebayo, my man, just a bit more pathos, okay? Look at the scuff mark on the floor like it represents all the dreams you’ve had to scrub away,” he’d say, and the crew would chuckle. Adebayo obeyed, his movements stiff, his face a stony mask. He felt like a prop in the museum of his own life. The true humiliation, however, came when they arrived at his flat. He had called Funke to warn her, a conversation filled with tense, brittle silences. She was there, with Amara strapped to her back, her face scrubbed of all expression. She had cleaned the room to within an inch of its life, but there was no hiding the peeling paint, the cracked mirror, the inherent smallness of their world.

The crew squeezed into the tiny space, their presence sucking the very air from the room. The director’s eyes lit up as he saw the cracked mirror. “Oh, this is gold. Pure gold,” he murmured to his cameraman. He tried to interview Funke, aiming his charming smile at her like a spotlight. “So, tell us,” he began, “what does it feel like, knowing your husband has this incredible, once-in-a-lifetime chance to lift you both out of… all this?” Funke looked at him, her gaze so direct and devoid of artifice that he faltered for a second. “It feels like my house is full of strangers with cameras,” she said, her voice quiet and clear. She answered every question with a blunt, unadorned fact, refusing to give them the tears or the trembling hope they were mining for. She would not perform for them. She would not sell her struggle for their story. Defeated, they turned their attention back to Adebayo, positioning him by the window, asking him to look out at the grey concrete wall of the next building as if he were gazing at a promised land.

That Saturday night, backstage was a riot of nervous energy, hairspray, and sequins. Adebayo stood in the wings, the borrowed clothes from the show’s stylist feeling like a costume for a stranger. He could hear the roar of the live audience, a sound like the ocean, vast and terrifying. He was due to sing a popular Afrobeats ballad that had been stripped down and rearranged into a soulless, acoustic number. Diana, his vocal coach, fussed around him, patting his chest. “Breathe, Adebayo. Diaphragm. And for heaven’s sake, connect with the camera. Seduce it. Make them fall in love with you,” she hissed, before being shooed away by a stage manager. Then, the lights in the studio dimmed.
